Usage Examples¶

Adding a task to a todo.txt file¶

 1"""Example how to add a task to an existing todo.txt file"""
 2import pytodotxt
 3
 4
 5todotxt = pytodotxt.TodoTxt("todo.txt")
 6todotxt.parse()
 7
 8new_task = pytodotxt.Task("(A) Do some more stuff")
 9todotxt.add(new_task)
10
11todotxt.save()

Instead of calling todotxt.add, you could of course also just call todotxt.tasks.append, but add will conveniently update new_task.todotxt and linenr.

Mark all tasks of a file as completed¶

 1"""How to mark tasks as completed"""
 2import datetime
 3
 4import pytodotxt
 5
 6
 7todotxt = pytodotxt.TodoTxt("todo.txt")
 8todotxt.parse()
 9
10for task in todotxt.parse():
11    if task.is_completed:
12        continue
13
14    task.completion_date = datetime.date.today()
15    task.is_completed = True
16
17todotxt.save()

Have your own custom Task subclass¶

 1"""How to customize your task class"""
 2import pytodotxt
 3
 4
 5class MyTask(pytodotxt.Task): pass
 6
 7
 8todotxt = pytodotxt.TodoTxt("todo.txt",
 9                            parser=pytodotxt.TodoTxtParser(task_type=MyTask))
10
11for task in todotxt.parse():
12    assert isinstance(task, MyTask)

Use the relaxed serialization when exporting¶

 1"""Example how to use the relaxed serialization"""
 2import pytodotxt
 3
 4todotxt = pytodotxt.TodoTxt("todo.txt",
 5                            serializer=pytodotxt.serialize_relaxed)
 6todotxt.parse()
 7
 8# Completed task with a completion date, but without creation date
 9# would lose the completion date with the default (pedantic) serializer
10new_task = pytodotxt.Task("x 2010-01-01 Prepare new year")
11todotxt.add(new_task)
12
13todotxt.save()
